subject: Re: [junit] Re: Changing junit.framework.Assert to instance methods
msgSnippet: ... You have several options: - create your own TestCase that doesn t extend the standard TestCase - create your own Assert class and delegate to it in your
messageBody:
> What I would like to know is the reason TestCase inherits from Assert
> rather than delegates to it. If it delegated, we could subclass
> TestCase to handle multiple failures and still use Assert for DbC.

You have several options:
- create your own TestCase that doesn't extend the standard TestCase
- create your own Assert class and delegate to it in your functional
TestCases

DbC's asserts are to be placed in the production code, and not (only) in
the test code. Like I said in a previous mail, you should prefer the
JDK1.4 assert keyword because it can be turned off when generating the
production release (if you don't use JDK1.4, well...).

HTH
